item.title: Evaluating Health Information Systems Using Ontologies
item.description: Evaluating Health Information Systems Using Ontologies Shahryar Eivazzadeh shahryar.eivazzadeh@bth.se Table of Contents Abstract Keywords 1. Introduction and Background 2. Method and Materials 3. Results 3.1. The UVON Method for Unifying the Evaluation Aspects 3.2. Result of the UVON Method Application in the FI-STAR Project 4. Discussion 4.1. Extending the Evaluation Utilizing the Ontology 4.2. Limitations of the UVON Method 5. Conclusion 6. Acknowledgment 7. Conflict of Interests 8.

item.title: From Technology to Health Information Technology
item.description: Table of Contents From Technology to Health Information Technology Health Technology Information Technology Health Information Technology & Systems Simorgh story and the persistence evaluation aspects References From Technology to Health Information Technology “Open the pod bay doors, HAL!” “I’m sorry, Dave. I’m afraid I can’t do that.” This scene is a turning point in the 2001: A Space Odyssey movie (1968) and novel when HAL 9000, the main computer of the spaceship and a symbol of top-notch technology, defies Dave Bowman the captain and main character of the story, suggesting that it was the one who plotted the murder of the crew in staged accidents.
